title: 114_s2773
content:
The "Gender Advancement in Pay Act" or "GAP Act" enhances the prohibition on wage discrimination. Section 6(d) of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to include provisions for differentials based on expertise and shift differentials, as well as factors such as education, training, or experience, in determining wages. The statute of limitations for actions involving violations of title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 is tolled if a charge is filed by an employee or on their behalf, until the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission or the Attorney General takes action or provides notification regarding the charge. The statute of limitations for Title VII violations under the Civil Rights Act of 1964 is tolled until the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission or Attorney General takes action or provides notification after a charge is filed. SEC. 3. NONRETALIATION PROVISION. Section 15 of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to include protections for employees who have made a charge, filed a complaint, testified, assisted in an investigation, or discussed wages. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to protect employees who disclose wage information of other employees in certain circumstances, and prohibits employers from requiring employees to sign contracts that prevent wage disclosure. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to protect employees who disclose wage information and prohibits employers from restricting wage disclosure. Employees who violate wage disclosure rules may be considered to have committed an unlawful act. SEC. 4. CIVIL PENALTY. Section 16(e) of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to include civil penalties for willful violations of section 6(d), with varying amounts based on the number of employees an employer has. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to include civil penalties for willful violations of section 6(d), with varying amounts based on the number of employees an employer has, ranging from $5,000 to $15,000. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to include civil penalties for willful violations of section 6(d), with varying amounts based on the number of employees an employer has, ranging from $5,000 to $15,000. Additionally, civil penalties collected for violations of section 6(d) shall be deposited in the account created under section 5(d) of the GAP Act. SEC. 5. STUDY ON HIGH-WAGE, HIGH-DEMAND OCCUPATIONS AND EQUIVALENT PAY. The Secretary of Labor and the Secretary of Education will conduct a joint study to increase women's participation in high-wage, high-demand occupations and industries where women are underrepresented. The Comptroller General of the United States will also conduct a study to develop strategies for this purpose. Reports on the findings and conclusions of these studies must be submitted to Congress within 2 years. The Secretary of Labor, Secretary of Education, and Comptroller General will conduct studies on increasing women's participation in underrepresented industries. Reports with findings and recommendations must be submitted to Congress within 2 years. The Secretary of Labor will manage funds for the studies. The Secretary of Labor will manage an account to conduct studies on increasing women's participation in underrepresented industries. Funds collected from civil penalties will be used for the studies, and the Secretary is authorized to withdraw and transfer funds as needed. SEC. 6. SMALL BUSINESS ASSISTANCE.

Effective Date: This Act and its amendments will take effect 6 months after enactment. The Secretary of Labor and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission will develop technical assistance materials for small businesses to comply with the Act. Small businesses are exempt from the Act to the same extent as the Fair Labor Standards Act.

SEC. 7. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. SEC. 7. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. Employers and employees must still comply with immigration laws and face penalties as required, regardless of this Act or any amendments.
